description.narrative: • Create access to SRHR information through in and out of school education • Create access to quality YFSRH through UBR health clinics and ensuring Government clinics comply to national standards • Raise awareness amongst (community) stakeholders and build their capacity to support and advocate for provision of SRHR education and services • Advocate with GoB for inclusion of UBR strategies and models in Government structures and strategies

activity-date.narrative: The collaboration of UBR with EKN started in 2011. In 2016, the funding for the programme “Unite for Body Rights (UBR), 2nd phase ” was agreed by the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands for another 4 years (i.e. 2016-2019). In December 2019, the project was further extended at ‘no-cost’ basis for two (2) months for the period of January & February and then costed extended will run for the period from March 2020 to December 2020.

sector.narrative: The goal of UBR II was, for all young people, living in poor rural and (semi) urban areas in 12 upazilas, irrespective of their age, gender, social background or sexual preference know their rights, take informed decisions about their sexual reproductive health and have access to high quality, youth friendly sexual reproductive health services within a supportive socio-cultural and political environment.

title.narrative: Outcome 1: Young people (10 – 19 year) living in rural and (semi) urban areas in 12 upazilas are increasingly aware of their SRH rights and have knowledge and skills to make informed decisions regarding their sexual reproductive health

Output 1.1.1: Master Trainers, SRHR trainers, SRHR Educators and Youth Organizers have the capacity to deliver CSE Output 1.1.2: Teachers in UBR schools & madrasahs in 12 upazila trained to deliver CSE and/NCTB-SRHR education Output 1.1.3: Target UBR schools & madrashas to include SRHR topic in their lesson plan Output 1.1.4: Youth Corners are established & functioning in schools & Madrasah
Outcome 2: Young people (10 – 24) living in rural and (semi) urban areas in 12 upazilas have access to Youth friendly SRHR services that adhere to the national standards.

Output 2.1.1: 750,000 Youth Friendly Services Provided to Young People Output 2.1.2: Referral system of YFSRHR Services established Output 2.1.3: Health Service Providers in Government health facilities are capacitated to provide Youth Friendly SRHR Services. Output 2.1.4: Youth Friendly SRHR Service monitoring system established Output 2.2.1: Teachers played role as psycho-social counselors for young people in schools
Outcome 3: An SRHR supportive environment ensured for sustainable access to Comprehensive Sexuality education (CSE) & Youth Friendly Services (YFS) in 12 Upazila

Output 3.1.1: Increased collaboration between UBR, SRHR partners and Government departments Output 3.1.4: Media people sensitized and play role in raising awareness on SRHR Output 3.2.1: 1243 community leaders and 19198 parents have increased awareness on SRHR Output 3.2.3: Community groups have capacity to use the social accountability tools to ensure the availability of health services Output3.3.1: 240 Youth Organizers in UBR2 Program are capacitated to take a role in advocacy
Outcome 4: Contribute to the development of (national) governmental policies and programs that include youth-friendly SRH education and services.

Output 4.1.1: Advocacy strategy in place for UBR Program Output 4.1.2: Joint Advocacy initiatives taken with Government stakeholders/Networks Output 4.1.3: Teachers and Head masters capacitate in playing advocacy role on SRHR Output 4.1.4: Government Officers are sensitized to implement CSE in schools and YFS service at health facilities for adolescent and young people Output 4.1.5: UBR YFS model adapted in government structure out of UBR Output 4.1.6: Linkage to include CSE in national curriculum and teachers training curriculum
